questions.text: A 9 month old baby was brought by the parents as she doesn't respond to their calls and was evaluated and found to have hearing loss. Which of the following would be a contraindication for cochlear implant in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cochlear aplasia

 

Explanation:

Cochlear aplasia is a contraindication of cochlear implantation.

 

Indications:

  • B/L severe (70-90 dB) to profound (>90 dB) SNHL (Option A)
  • Prelingual deafness: A child who is born deaf and has not yet developed speech. (Option C)
  • Post lingual deafness: Child/adult who has become deaf but has already developed speech.

 

Contraindications:

  • Cochlear aplasia (Option B)
  • 8th nerve abnormality (like aplasia or retrocochlear pathology, conduction via the auditory nerve is dysfunctional)
  • Central auditory lesions
  • Michel aplasia: Complete absence of the bony and membranous labyrinth, including the petrous apex, while the external and middle ears remain unaffected.

 

Prerequisites:

  • Age in prelingual deafness: Minimum age as early as possible, maximum age 7 years (Option D)
  • There is no age limit for post-lingual deafness
  • Failed trial of hearing aid
  • Intact acoustic nerve and central hearing tract

questions.text: In a cochlear implant, what is the primary role of the external speech processor?

choices.text: To amplify sound before it reaches the brain
To convert captured sound into digital signals
To stimulate the auditory nerve directly
To provide power to the internal components

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) To convert captured sound into digital signals

 

Explanation:

A cochlear implant consists of external and internal components.

External Component: Contains microphone, speech processor and a transmitter.

  • Microphone captures sound and the speech processor converts it into digital signals (Option B)
  • Transmitter sends digital signals to the internal implant across the skin.

                             Fig: Components of Cochlear implant

Internal Component: Contains receiver/stimulator and an electrode array.

  • Receiver/ Stimulator converts the digital signals into electrical impulses and transmits them to the electrode array situated inside the cochlea.
  • The electrode array stimulates the auditory nerve (Option C)

 

Amplification is the role of hearing aids. Cochlear implants focus on processing and transmitting sound information rather than amplifying it. (Option A) The internal receiver/stimulator is powered by a battery housed in the external component but not supplied directly by the speech processor. (Option D)

                                         Fig: Internal Receiver

questions.text: Where is the electrode array placed during cochlear implant surgery to ensure effective stimulation of the auditory nerves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Scala tympani

 

Explanation:

The electrode array is placed in the scala tympani to ensure proximity to spiral ganglion cells for effective stimulation of auditory nerve fibers, facilitating sound perception.

 

Surgical Procedure:

  • A two-layered flap approach is typically used: the first layer consists of skin and subcutaneous tissue, followed by a musculoperiosteal flap.
  • A pocket is created beneath the second flap, and a recess is drilled into the bone for the receiver/stimulator.

 

Surgical Techniques:

Facial Recess Approach:

  • Involves a cortical mastoidectomy to identify the incus and semicircular canal, followed by a posterior tympanotomy.
  • Cochleostomy is performed near the round window membrane, creating an opening of 1.0-1.6 mm for the electrode.

 

Pericanal Techniques:

  • Involves elevating a tympanomeatal flap to perform a cochleostomy, either through an endaural or postaural approach.
  • A bony tunnel is drilled from the external canal to the middle ear.
  • Examples include the Veria and suprameatal recess techniques.

 

Electrode Insertion and Testing:

  • The device is secured, and the electrode array is gradually inserted through the cochleostomy. The electrode entry site is sealed with fascia or periosteum to prevent perilymph leakage.
  • Electrophysiological testing confirms proper electrode function.

 

Complications of cochlear implant surgery:

Early Complications
  • Facial paralysis
  • Wound infection
  • Wound dehiscence
  • Flap necrosis
  • Electrode migration
  • Device failure
  • CSF leak
  • Meningitis
  • Post-operative dizziness/vertigo

Late Complications
  • Exposure of device and extrusion
  • Pain at the site of implant
  • Migration and displacement of device
  • Late device failure
  • Otitis media

 

  • Postoperative care involves activating the implant 3-4 weeks after surgery and regular programming for optimization.
  • Rehabilitation emphasizes auditory-verbal therapy to develop listening and speaking skills, necessitating collaboration among the patient, family, and professionals.

 

Round Window Membrane: Acts as a barrier, not a placement area. (Option A)

 

Eustachian Tube: Connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, unrelated to cochlear implantation. (Option C)

 

Outer Ear Canal: Part of the external ear, not involved in implantation. (Option D)

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with microtia and chronic ear discharge is being evaluated for hearing rehabilitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate hearing device for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bone-Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA)

 

Explanation:

Bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA) captures the sound and transmits vibrations to the skull, stimulating the cochlea directly and bypassing the external auditory canal and middle ear. It is used when the air conduction method of rehabilitation cannot be used.

 

Components:

  • Titanium Fixture: Surgically embedded in the skull. It bonds with the surrounding skin (osseointegration)
  • Titanium Abutment: Connects the sound processor.
  • Sound Processor: Attached after osseointegration (2 to 6 months after implantation).

Indication:

  • Chronic ear discharge.
  • Single-sided hearing loss.
  • Children with microtia, anotia, canal atresia.
  • Conductive or mixed hearing loss (e.g., otosclerosis, tympanosclerosis) with contraindications for surgery.
  • Following MRM (large mastoid cavity).
  • Excessive feedback or discomfort from AC hearing aids.
  • Age of implantation: >5yrs

 

Surgical Procedure:

  • Adults typically have a single-stage surgery with a 3-month osseointegration wait.
  • Children usually undergo a two-stage procedure, with the fixture placed first and the abutment connected after 6 months.

 

Traditional behind-the-ear hearing aid (Option A): Ineffective due to the absence of a functional ear canal in microtia.

 

Air-conduction hearing aid (Option B): Unsuitable as it depends on sound travelling through a compromised ear canal.

 

CROS hearing aid (Option D): The most appropriate hearing solution for a patient with conditions of microtia and chronic ear discharge, as in this patient, would be BAHA.

CROS (Contralateral Routing of Signals) hearing aids are designed for patients with unilateral hearing loss who have an intact ear on the opposite side. In this case, the child's microtia indicates a structural issue on one side, and chronic discharge may also compromise the use of a CROS system effectively.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with neurofibromatosis type 2 has undergone bilateral vestibular schwannoma resection and now experiences profound hearing loss. Which implant would be most suitable for this patient to restore some auditory function?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Auditory Brainstem Implant (ABI)

 

Explanation:

Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) often involves B/L vestibular schwannomas, which can damage the auditory nerve during resection. Auditory Brainstem Implant bypasses the need for an intact auditory nerve by directly stimulating the brainstem.

ABI is appropriate for this patient, as it directly stimulates the brainstem despite the severed cochlear nerve.

 

Auditory brainstem implant

  • Used when the 8th nerve has a lesion.
  • Electrode bypasses the cochlea and 8th nerve; it directly stimulates the brain stem.
  • The implant stimulates the cochlear nucleus directly, and then impulses are carried to the auditory cortex.
  • Position of the implant- lateral recess of the 4th ventricle.

                                            Fig: Auditory brainstem implant

 

Indications:

  • B/L acoustic neuromas
  • CP angle tumor
  • B/L Cochlear aplasia
  • B/L Cochlear nerve aplasia


 

Cochlear Implant Requires an intact cochlear nerve, which is severed in this patient. (Option A)

 

BAHA is designed for conductive hearing loss and relies on a functional cochlear nerve. (Option C)

 

Middle Ear Implant amplifies sound for conductive loss but also needs a functioning cochlear nerve. (Option D)

 

Middle ear implant:

Middle ear implants operate using a direct drive mechanism, delivering mechanical vibrations directly to the ossicular chain while keeping the ear canal open. It has 2 types:

  • Piezoelectric Devices: These use an electric current through a piezoceramic crystal to produce vibrations that drive the ossicles. Examples are Envoy MET, Rion, and TICA.
  • Electromagnetic Devices: These generate a magnetic field via an electric current in a coil, which moves an attached magnet to convey vibrations to the cochlea.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss is recommended for an In-the-Canal (ITC) hearing aid. What is a key characteristic of this type of hearing aid?

choices.text: It is worn entirely behind the ear.
It fits partially in the ear canal, making it less noticeable.
It provides amplification for all frequency ranges equally

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It fits partially in the ear canal, making it less noticeable.

 

Explanation:

Conventional Hearing Aids
Hearing aids amplify sounds for individuals with hearing loss and consist of three main parts:

  1. Microphone: Captures sound and converts it into electrical signals.
  2. Amplifier: Enhances these electrical signals.
  3. Receiver: Transforms the amplified signals back into sound, transmitted through an earmold to the tympanic membrane.

                                     Fig: Parts of a Hearing Aid

 

Types of Hearing Aids

  • Air-Conduction Hearing Aids: Deliver sound through the ear canal to the tympanic membrane.
  • Bone-Conduction Hearing Aids: Use a bone vibrator to directly stimulate the cochlea, ideal for those with draining ears or canal atresia.

 

Common Air-Conduction Aids:

  • Body-Worn Aids: Components worn at chest level, suitable for severe hearing loss with minimal feedback.
  • Behind-the-Ear (BTE) Aids: All components in a unit are worn behind the ear, which is effective for mild to moderate high-frequency loss. (Option A)
  • Spectacle Aids: Integrated into eyeglass frames; less common now.
  • In-the-Ear (ITE) Aids: Housed in an earmold, good for mild to moderate loss, favored for aesthetics.
  • Canal Aids (ITC and CIC): Small aids fitting into the ear canal; ITC aids are partially visible (Option C), while CIC aids are discreet and almost invisible. ITC amplify specific frequencies, which is especially beneficial for high-frequency hearing loss (Option D)

Indications
Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be treated medically or surgically, including:

  • Sensorineural Hearing Loss: Impacts daily activities; some may experience sound distortion.
  • Deaf Children: Early fitting is critical for speech and learning; binaural aids are preferred for severe cases.
  • Conductive Deafness: Used when surgical options are not feasible.

 

Contralateral Routing of Signals (CROS)

  • This method uses a microphone on the deaf side to transmit sound to the better ear, aiding sound localization.
  • Bone-Anchored Hearing Aids (BAHA) are increasingly favored for single-sided deafness over CROS aids.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a dental cavity that has been causing significant discomfort for the past few days. He now reports a new onset of ear pain on the same side as the toothache. Which of the following nerves is most likely involved in transmitting the pain from the dental cavity to the ear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Auriculotemporal nerve

Explanation:

The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) from the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), supplies sensation to the skin of the temple and parts of the external ear. It also transmits sensory information from the lower teeth and gums. When a patient experiences dental pain along with ear pain on the same side, it is often due to referred pain.

Otalgia:

Otalgia refers to pain in the ear and can be classified based on its cause.

Primary Otalgia: Pain originates from the ear itself.

Examples of Causes:

  • Ear wax in the external auditory canal (EAC)
  • Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM)
  • Otitis externa
  • Foreign body in the ear

Referred Otalgia: Pain originates from another region of the body but is felt in the ear due to shared nerve pathways.

Nerve Supply of the Ear

Pinna (External Ear)
  • Greater auricular nerve (C2, C3)
  • Lesser Occipital nerve (C2, C3)
  • Auriculotemporal nerve (Branch of Trigeminal nerve - V3)
  • Arnold's nerve (Auricular branch of Vagus nerve - X)
  • Facial nerve (VII)

External Auditory Canal (EAC)
  • Auriculotemporal nerve (Trigeminal nerve - V3)
  • Arnold's nerve (Vagus nerve - X)
  • Facial nerve (VII)

Tympanic membrane
  • Auriculotemporal nerve (Trigeminal nerve - V3)
  • Arnold's nerve (Auricular branch of Vagus nerve - X)
  • Jacobson's nerve (Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve)


Mechanisms and Causes of Referred Otalgia:

Referred otalgia occurs when a lesion or pathology in another part of the body irritates a nerve that also innervates the ear. Below are examples of referred otalgia, associated nerves, and areas of involvement:

Fig: Mechanisms of Referred Otalgia

 

Lesion Location

Associated Nerve

Pathway for Referred Otalgia

Oropharynx, Posterior 1/3 of tongue, Tonsils, Posterior Pharyngeal Wall

Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX)

Jacobson's nerve mediates pain from pharyngeal structures to the ear.

Larynx, Hypopharynx, Cervical Esophagus

Vagus nerve (X)

Arnold's nerve transmits pain from the larynx and esophagus to the ear.

Cervical Spine (Cervical Spondylosis, C2-C3)

Lesser occipital nerve, Greater auricular nerve (C2, C3)

These nerves can cause ear pain in cervical spine conditions.

Temporo-mandibular Joint (TMJ)

Trigeminal nerve (V3), Auriculotemporal nerve

Pain from the TMJ can be referred to the ear via the auriculotemporal nerve.

Teeth, Parotid, Anterior 2/3 of tongue

Trigeminal nerve (V3)

Dental pain, parotid pathologies, and tongue lesions may cause ear pain via the trigeminal nerve.

Nose and Sinuses

Trigeminal nerve (V2, V3)

Sinus infections and nasal issues may refer pain to the ear.

Oesophagus, Hypopharynx, Larynx

Vagus nerve (X)

Conditions like GERD or laryngeal cancer can cause referred ear pain.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of a persistent ringing sound in his left ear for the past few months, more noticeable at night when he is in quiet environments. He denies any hearing loss or ear discharge. Otoscopic examination is normal, and audiometry shows normal hearing. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Perform an MRI to rule out acoustic neuroma
Reassure the patient and consider tinnitus retraining therapy
Advise complete avoidance of noise exposure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reassure the patient and consider tinnitus retraining therapy

 

Explanation:

  • Tinnitus is often a symptom and not a disease. Since the patient’s examination and audiometry are normal, the best initial approach is reassurance and educating the patient that this is a benign condition.
  • Tinnitus retraining therapy (TRT), which includes counseling and sound therapy, is an effective treatment that helps patients habituate to the sound of tinnitus and diminishes the emotional response to it. This therapy aims to uncouple the brain's emotional and physiological reactions to tinnitus, eventually leading to less awareness of the symptom.

 

Tinnitus:

Tinnitus is characterized by the perception of ringing sounds in the ear which are not external. It can be classified into two main types:

 

 

Subjective Tinnitus

Objective Tinnitus

Definition

The ringing sensation is only experienced by the patient and cannot be detected or measured by an examiner.

Tinnitus is associated with an identifiable organic cause that can be detected by both the patient and the examiner.

Causes

Otologic:

  • Tympanic membrane perforation
  • Ear wax accumulation
  • Fluid in the middle ear
  • Chronic otitis media
  • Ménière's disease
  • Presbycusis (age-related hearing loss)
  • Noise-induced hearing loss
  • Acoustic neuroma
 

Metabolic:

  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Hyperdynamic circulation
  • Obesity
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Vitamin deficiency (e.g., B12)
 

Neurologic:

  • Brain stroke
  • Brain infarction
  • Head trauma
  • Fractures
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Postmeningitic hearing loss
 

Cardiovascular:

  • Anemia
  • Hypertension
  • Hypotension
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Hyperdynamic circulation
 

Pharmacologic:

  • Ototoxic drugs (e.g., certain antibiotics, diuretics)
 

Psychogenic:

  • Tinnitus without identifiable physical findings; often associated with Anxiety, depression, stress

Vascular (synchronized with pulse - Pulsatile tinnitus):

  • AV fistula
  • Dehiscence of the carotid artery
  • Glomus tumor of middle ear
  • Jugular bulb abnormalities
  • Carotid aneurysm
  • Carotid stenosis
  • Vascular loop pressing on cranial nerve VIII
  • High-riding carotid artery
  • Persistent stapedial artery
 

Patulous Eustachian Tube: Tinnitus synchronized with respiration

 

Other causes:

  • Palatal myoclonus
  • TMJ disorders
  • Idiopathic stapedial myoclonus

 

Treatment of Tinnitus

1. Unknown Cause

  • Retraining Therapy: In cases where the cause is unknown, supportive care and monitoring are essential. This may include lifestyle modifications and hearing protection.

 

2. Subjective Tinnitus

Patient Counseling:

  • Education and Support: Providing information about tinnitus and its management.
  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Helps patients manage the psychological impact of tinnitus.
  • Sound Therapy: Involves using background noise to help mask tinnitus, reducing the perception of the ringing sound. Tinnitus maskers are specialized devices that generate white noise or soothing sounds to cover up the tinnitus, offering relief.
  • Tinnitus Retraining Therapy (TRT) combines sound therapy with counseling to help the brain habituate to the tinnitus sound, aiming to make it less noticeable over time.

 

3. Objective Tinnitus

Treatment of Underlying Cause:

  • Vascular Issues: Surgical or interventional procedures to address vascular abnormalities.
  • Patulous Eustachian Tube: Management strategies may include nasal saline sprays or other treatments to stabilize the Eustachian tube.

 

Prescribe an antidepressant (Option A): Antidepressants or medications may be considered in the management of tinnitus if the patient has accompanying depression or anxiety.

 

Perform an MRI to rule out acoustic neuroma (Option B): While MRI may be necessary in cases where tinnitus is unilateral or associated with hearing loss to rule out an acoustic neuroma (a benign tumor of the vestibulocochlear nerve), this patient lacks these findings.

 

Advise complete avoidance of noise exposure (Option D): Although noise-induced hearing loss is a known cause of tinnitus, complete avoidance of noise is not recommended. Instead, controlled sound therapy, like using tinnitus maskers or background noise generators, is helpful in patients with tinnitus, especially at night.
